content.description:
The crux comes early with the overhanging hand crack.  Once you get past this pull yourself into the batshit .8 or so squeeze chimney.  There is an old bolt (no hanger) somewhere in there.  It is a pretty cool position in this part as there is nothing beneath you.  The 'stairway' part is fairly mellow at .8 or .9.  Here we chose to keep traversing, but you should probably pull the roof.  It looks much harder and more fun.  Belay and walk off or down-climb to the chain anchors below.

Note:  We might've done a variation to the tradition route by traversing under the final roof.  It seemed like the natural line at the time.

Overall, it is a fun worthwhile climb.  Be warned, this route will have more loose rock than its neighbors.
content.protection:
There is a manky bolt (no hanger) in the chimney and bolt for an anchor at the belay on top. Bring doubles of your widest, although protection in the chimney is mostly psychological. You can get a great #2 at the top of the chimney.

5/13/2020 - From the comments and rumors, there have been bolts added to the stairway.

climbs.name: Someone's in the Kitchen with Dina

content.description:
Someone's in the Kitchen with Dina

is a great trad route uses large to medium gear. Takes all trad gear well. I used nuts and hex's my buddy used cams. Follow the crack right of Earwig to the same chains. If you wanted to you could clip Earwigs bolts, some of the clips would be a stretch, but it's suppose to be lead with trad gear. Which Is the way I would recommend climbing it.
content.location: Hike to Knightland take the second carn on the right. Follow the cliff face up to the climb.

content.description: Starts above "Earwig" behind the small pine. Low- angle beginning. It's quite dirty. The last few moves can be kind of fun for some people.
content.protection: 11+ bolts, one every 3 feet average. 2 bolts for the anchor. You could skip a few bolts at the bottom with ease.
content.location: This is the furthest route above "Stairway." It's quite short, about 30 feet. Located 15 feet above "Earwig."

content.description: Good warm up traverse or perhaps something to do while others are climbing. Still some loose rock at spots, but it's a great traverse. There are a couple of parts where the feet thin out a bit which makes it fun. Lots of crimps and mini-sidepulls.
content.location:
Start right of the big bush directly beneath the start of

Stairway to Heaven

. Traverse right past

Earwig

. The tree that is just a few feet away from the cliff is about the half-way point. Go all the way until your reach the ledge next to where the tree blocks the traverse route.

content.description: Shares start with Frog Kisser, continues right up white west facing face. Sustained climbing.
content.location: Route west and just around arete of stairway crack. Climbs white west face

content.description: "Frog Kisser", rated 5.7 to 5.8, 12 bolts plus anchors. 100 feet to the top, climb left of the dihedral on the black slab. 60 meter rope needed. Crux is between bolt 9 and 11. Mantel ledge to the last bolt, anchor just out of sight up the crack.
content.protection: 12 Rawl/Powers bolts with Fixe hangers. Installed September 2013. Anchor is all the way to the top (note: chain got stolen, there's a Fixe ring and just a regular hanger as of July 6 2015). Anchor can be easily accessed from the top for top-roping, too.
content.location: "Frog Kisser" is located 30 feet west of the StairWay crack, sort of below and around the corner. "Frog Kisser" is one route left/down hill/west of "Good Ship Lollipop," .11d, the steep white face. They share the first 2 bolts.

content.description: Climb the slab face left of the crack using small edges and an occasional mantle. Climbing stays pretty consistent, with the crux at the top. Rated 5.9 if you don't use the crack.
content.location:
Hike up to

Knightland

on the obvious trail, turn right at the second cairn and continue up the slop next to the cliff face to the climb.
